newsitem.title: USA: CBOT wheat ends lower on Australian crop forecast.
newsitem.headline: CBOT wheat ends lower on Australian crop forecast.

text.p: CBOT wheat futures closed lower and new contract lows were set on a hike in an estimate for Australia's 1996-97 wheat production, traders said.
"Wheat fell below $4.00 (December). Everybody's talking about the Australian estimate," said Ron Kucha of O'Connor and Co.
The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) said the 1996-97 Australian wheat crop would total 20.9 million tonnes, up from ABARE's previous estimate for 18.8 million tonnes.
A late surge in soy gave wheat underpinning at the close.

December ended below $4.00 per bushel, the lowest level for a nearby contract since June 1995 and an important psychological benchmark support area. Technicians cite support now at $3.98 and $3.92 per bushel for the December contract.
A new contract low of $3.87-1/2 a bushel was set in the March, down from the previous low of $3.92 set Monday.
Wheat already was struggling with slack exports and building competition from the European Union, Argentina, Canada and Australia, the traders said.
Wheat closed one to three cents per bushel lower, with December down one at $3.99-1/2.
Traders said the key moving averages indicate the market remains bearish but the short term indicators indicate an oversold scenario.
December's nine day relative strength index (RSI) closed at 22.333 points. The market generally considers an RSI of 20 or less as indicative of a very oversold market.
Key sellers included Prudential Securities and Refco Inc each with two million bushels sold in the December, traders said.
Wheat futures volume was estimated at 16,000 contracts, up from 15,488 Monday, according to the CBOT.
Wheat options volume was estimated at 10,000 contracts, up from 4,154 Monday.
